snippet: In settling a lawsuit, Florida agreed that residents who were removed from voting rolls after mistakenly being classified as noncitizens will be allowed to vote in November.
abstract: Florida residents who were mistakenly removed from the voter rolls because the state classified them as non-citizens will be returned to the rolls and allowed to vote in November; Florida Department of State also agrees to inform the 2,625 residents that they are once again eligible to vote; agreement stems from a lawsuit charging that the so-called voter purge was discriminatory because it singled out mostly immigrants.
lead_paragraph: In settling a lawsuit, Florida agreed that residents who were removed from voting rolls after mistakenly being classified as noncitizens will be allowed to vote in November.

headline.seo: Florida Agrees to Let Citizens Mistakenly Purged From Rolls to Vote
headline.main: After Mistakenly Purging Citizens, Florida Agrees to Let Them Vote
headline.print_headline: After Mistakenly Purging Citizens, Florida Agrees to Let Them Vote
